description.plain:
Method Man (born Clifford Smith on March 2, 1971) is a Grammy-winning rapper and actor who is one of the breakout members of Staten Island’s Wu-Tang Clan. On their seminal 1993 debut album Enter the Wu-Tang: 36 Chambers, Mr. Mef made his name known with his namesake solo track among other standout appearances throughout the album. He was also the first member of the group to release a solo album after the Wu crew debut when he put out Tical in 1994.

In 1996, Method Man won a Grammy with Mary J. Blige in the Best Rap Performance by a Duo or Group category for their collaboration “I’ll Be There for You/You’re All I Need.” Meth has gone on to release several solo albums while continuing to contribute to Wu-Tang projects, and he also released two collaborative albums with his partner-in-rhyme Redman in 1999 (Blackout!) and 2009 (Blackout! 2).

He parlayed his success in the music business into television and film roles. He has appeared in The Wire, Belly, The Breaks, The Deuce, Luke Cage, and he’s the host of the rap battle TV show Drop the Mic. He also starred alongside Redman in their short-lived FOX sitcom Method & Red and the movie How High, which is named after their 1995 collaboration. He has also been featured in multiple Def Jam fighting video games, including Def Jam Vendetta and Def Jam Fight For NY.

songs.full_title: Bring the Pain by Method Man
songs.title: Bring the Pain

description.plain:
“Bring the Pain” is a hit track by the Wu Tang Clan’s Method Man. “B-the-P” was the first single released from Meth’s solo debut album “Tical.”

Released November 15, 1994, on Def Jam Records, “Tical” was an immediate commercial success. It reached #4 on the Billboard 200, and #1 on the Top R&B/Hip Hop Albums chart. On January 18, 1995, the album was certified gold in sales by the RIAA. On July 13, 1995, it was certified platinum after sales of one million copies.

In a 1997 interview with MTV, Method Man elaborated on why the song was titled “Bring the Pain”

That’s why I named that joint ‘Bring the Pain,’ because everybody screaming they’re real. What’s real in this world really? Pain. You can’t hide pain. Once it hits you, you’re struck.

Comedian Chris Rock named his 1996 tour and television special “Bring the Pain” after this song. 2Pac also references the song in the No More Pain. Interestingly, Meth did a feature on the track “Got My Mind Made Up” from the same album, but apparently it was intended to be a Dogg Pound track at first. Death Row reworked other material they had been creating and let 2Pac use it for All Eyez on Me when he got out of jail. Apparently Raekwon and Inspectah Deck, but were dropped when 2Pac’s verse was added. Given that Meth was left on the track as well as given a shout out it would seem 2Pac was a big fan. It could have something to do with the sketchy sounding meeting he had a with Meth in LA some time later.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aAqZBNYkOm4

songs.full_title: All I Need by Method Man
songs.title: All I Need

description.plain:
The 4th track from Method Man’s debut album “Tical” (1994).
This classic song became  immediately a classic in the ‘90s, thanks to the heartfelt lines that provide a perfect picture of Meth’s love for this woman, in a moment where rap music was considered to be deeply misogynist.



The track received so much attention, that would eventually be remixed several times by RZA and Puff Daddy, to become a Grammy winning, smashing hit in 1995, thanks to Mary J. Blige collaboration.

First single off of Method Man’s third studio album, Tical 0: The Prequel.
Sample from “Dum Maro Dum,” by Asha Bhosle. The song appears on Def Jam Fight For NY, a hip-hop fighting game in which Method Man and Busta Rhymes portray themselves.

songs.full_title: I’ll Be There For You/You’re All I Need To Get By (Razor Sharp Mix) by Method Man (Ft. Mary J. Blige)
songs.title: I’ll Be There For You/You’re All I Need To Get By (Razor Sharp Mix)
songs.title_with_featured: I’ll Be There For You/You’re All I Need To Get By (Razor Sharp Mix) (Ft. Mary J. Blige)

description.plain:
The song is a remix of Method Man’s “All I Need” (which appears on the same album Tical), with an interpolation of Marvin Gaye and Tammi Terrell’s 1968 hit, “You’re All I Need to Get By”, with Mary J. Blige singing the choruses, and backing vocals. The song also ended up winning the duo the Grammy Award for Best Rap Performance by a Duo or Group in 1996.

In 2008, it was ranked #44 on VH1’s “100 Greatest Songs of Hip Hop” list.
In 2009, Method Man and Mary J. Blige performed the song together at VH1’s 6th Annual Hip Hop Honors ceremony. The song is often cited as the hybrid of what’s now known as “Thug-Loved” duets.
In 2012, Complex ranked the song #1 on its list of “The 25 Best Hip-Hop Love Songs”.

songs.full_title: What the Blood Clot!?! by Method Man
songs.title: What the Blood Clot!?!

description.plain:
In a 2011 interview with Complex, Meth claimed this song was written while he was upset at the rest of the Wu:

“I remember when I wrote ‘What The Blood Clot,’ I was on an airplane. [Me and the Wu-Tang had] argued about some shit. I forget what, but I knew I was just mad at niggas. That whole verse I was just shooting at everybody on my team. [Laughs.] I was mad as shit."

He went on to say, “I was writing to ‘It’s All In The Mind’ off Eric Sermon’s No Pressure. That’s what I wrote ‘What The Blood Clot’ off of.”

songs.artist_names: Method Man (Ft. Blue Raspberry, Carlton Fisk, Inspectah Deck, RZA & Streetlife)
songs.full_title: Mr. Sandman by Method Man (Ft. Blue Raspberry, Carlton Fisk, Inspectah Deck, RZA & Streetlife)
songs.title: Mr. Sandman
songs.title_with_featured: Mr. Sandman (Ft. Blue Raspberry, Carlton Fisk, Inspectah Deck, RZA & Streetlife)

description.plain:
The obligatory Wu-Tang posse cut off of Method Man’s solo debut Tical. The track boasts a classic verse from Inspectah Deck and great performances from RZA, Streetlife, Carlton Fisk, and of course, Meth himself.

The track gets it’s title from The Chordettes' 1954 song “Mr. Sandman”, which Wu-affiliate Blue Raspberry interpolates in the intro and chorus.

annotatable.link_title: Mr. Sandman by Method Man (Ft. Blue Raspberry, Carlton Fisk, Inspectah Deck, RZA & Streetlife)
annotatable.title: Mr. Sandman

body.plain:
The obligatory Wu-Tang posse cut off of Method Man’s solo debut Tical. The track boasts a classic verse from Inspectah Deck and great performances from RZA, Streetlife, Carlton Fisk, and of course, Meth himself.

The track gets it’s title from The Chordettes' 1954 song “Mr. Sandman”, which Wu-affiliate Blue Raspberry interpolates in the intro and chorus.

songs.lyrics:
Mr. Sandman Lyrics[Intro: RZA & Blue Raspberry]
This is (Mr. Sandman, bring me a good dream)
Serious, the craziest, da-da
(Mr. Sandman, bring me a good dream)
Day-da, danger, dangerous style

[Verse 1: RZA]
Lyrical shots from the Glock
Bust bullet holes on the charts
I want the number one spot
What's the science? I'm a giant
New York defiant, brutal like domestic violence
Silence of the Lambs, occurred when I slammed in
Program the jams to be fat as Ralph Kramden
Others come with shit as silly as Art Carney
But my technique tranquilizes more kids than Barney
Remedy for stress is three bags of sess
A day at my rest playin' chess, yes!
My thoughts be sneaky like a crook from Brooklyn
When you ain't lookin', I take the queen with the rook then
I get vexed, layin' phat tracks on Ampex
Puffin' skunk, gettin' drunk off of Triple X
Ballantine's, I got more love than Valentine
The violent mind, I blast wit' a silent nine!
[Verse 2: Inspectah Deck & (Method Man)]
My hazardous thoughts to cut the mic's life support short
Brains get stained like tablecloths when I let off
Powerful poetry pushed past the point of no return
Leavin' mics with third-degree burns
Let me at 'em! I grip your style like a spasm
Drag 'em through the mud then I bag 'em
We're screamin' hardcore, hip-hop drips out my pores
And I be raw, for four score plus seven more
I strike like a bowling ball, holdin' y'all hostage like jail
Electrifyin' like the third rail
Beats are smashed with paragraphs of ruckus
Wu-Tang! (Clan ain't nuthin' to fuck wit'!)

[Verse 3: Method Man]
Ha! Hot time, summer in the city
My people represent, get busy
The heat-seeker, on a mission from Hell's Kitchen
I gets in where I fits in
For head-touchin', listen
Enemy is the industry, got me flippin'!
I don't give a fuck! Tell that bitch and her nigga
I'm killin', snipin', catchin' murder cases
Desert Stormin', I be searchin' for oasis
As I run a mile wit' a racist
Pullin' swords, hit the Billboard wit' a bullet
Peace to the number seven
Everybody else get the fo'-nine-three-eleven
You might also like[Chorus: Method Man & Blue Raspberry]
Mr. Sandman, bring me a good dream
I don't know what's going on, if you can take us there

[Verse 4: Streetlife]
Yo, watch me bang the headpiece, there's no survival
My flow lights up the block like a homicidal
Murder, underground beef for the burger
P.L.O., criminal thoughts you never heard of
I switch, the city never sleeps, life's a bitch
I shit, runnin' through bitches like Emmitt Smith
Caution, niggas best to be careful crossin'
The street, before they end up layin' in a coffin
Don't sleep, niggas tend to forget, however
Peep this — my nigga Kase lives forever

[Verse 5: Carlton Fisk]
What evil lurks in the heart of men?
It be the Shadow, street-life, flowin' again
I had a plot, scheme, I knew for sure
Only one kick would knock the hinges off the door
The dread tried to jet, Sabrina at his neck
Thirteen pounds on the table plus a tech
Just when I said, "Where the fuck's the C.R.E.A.M.?"
Another dread came out the kitchen with the M-16
He tried to cock it, blast three shots like rockets
Crushed his collarbone, ripped his arm out the socket
My move for the table was swift, I got my hostage
(The nigga tried to stab you, God!) but I dodged it
Niggas said, "Carlton, you's a ill motherfucker"
'Cause I made it look like they both killed each other
And I'm out
[Chorus: Blue Raspberry]
Mr. Sandman, bring me a good dream
Mr. Sandman, bring me a good dream

[Outro: Method Man & RZA]
You know what I'm sayin'?
Tical5Embed

First, there was the collapse of civilization
Anarchy, genocide, starvation
Then, when it seemed like shit couldn't get any more fucked up
We got the Plague, the Living Death
Closing his icy grip around the whole planet
Then the rumors started
The last hardcore MCs were working on the cure, that would end the pestilence
Why?
I like the death

I like this world
The Final Frontier
These are the voyages of the Starship Tical
[Verse 1: Method Man]

Before I blow back off the map, contact

songs.full_title: Sweet Love by Method Man (Ft. Cappadonna & Streetlife)
songs.title: Sweet Love

description.plain:
Sweet Love is the sixth track off Method Man’s sophomore album “Tical 2000: Judgement Day”.

It was produced by the RZA’s pupil True Master and it features guest appearance from Cappadonna and Streetlife.

On the track the artists describe their sexual relation with women.

songs.lyrics:
Sweet Love Lyrics[Produced by True Master]

[Intro: Streetlife]
Excuse me gorgeous..

[Verse 1: Streetlife]
Just maxing, looking for hoes, y'know, relaxing
Met this redbone Jasmine, midtown Manhattan
Shot a verb, that tranked her nerves, calm words
Massaged the mentals, made her pussycat purr
Sweet Love you look miraculous, brown-eyed passionate
High cheek-boned, Tommy Girl cologne you smashing it
Jump in, take a spin, destination Staten
I have you home by ten, shorty started laughing
She replied, "Street, you ever ride while you drive?"
I looked puzzled, and said, "Nah baby, why?"
She pressed up, grabbed my dick, threw her dress up
Cocked her legs, cold fucked my head up
Now I'm deep in it, flying past the speed limit
Out of control, still whipping it, steadily hitting it
Deep stroking, one hand on the wheel, blunt smoking
Loving how it feel, sweet Love you got me open, what?
[Verse 2: Cappadonna]

songs.title: The Purple Tape
songs.title_with_featured: The Purple Tape (Ft. Inspectah Deck, Raekwon & Rae Smith)

description.plain:
“The Purple Tape” is a track on The Meth Lab album, the fifth album of Method Man.

Wu-Tang Clan’s Method Man, Raekwon, and Inspectah Deck team up. Optimally timed, “Purple Tape” arrives following the 20-year anniversary of Rae’s benchmark solo debut, which Meth’ and Rebel I.N.S. both worked on as well.

The 2015 track uses ’95 as inspiration. Mef’s son, Rae Butta—who even in the song announces that he’s “no relation to Chef” provides the chorus, as Brown Bag AllStars’ J57 affords the beat. The three decorated veterans channel back to those basement sessions in RZA’s Staten Island, New York studio to find the flows and rugged imagery worthy of the purple plastic mention.

The Meth Lab Lyrics[Intro]

[Verse 1: Method Man]
Welcome to the Meth Lab, listen, it's time to cook
Not confessions of a video vixen, we by the book
Start the fire, I can tell what you thinkin' just by a look
I'm a crook, like some fish in a barrel, I got 'em hooked
Blame the Method, your sanity took, go 'head, admit it
You a meth head that live on the edge, just need a push
I'm your pusher, supplier, I'm back, the cheese on the wire

Now the kids earnin' like them dealers that he admire

Hazardous material, you'd need a hazmat suit
Now you lookin' at me like, 'What's a hazmat suit?'
Somethin' used to move a body, you don't have that loop
[Bridge 1]
Let's talk about trust
I told you not to cook my recipe
And you went ahead and did it anyway
Cause I never said I wouldn't cook it
Cause it ain't yours, it's ours, bitch

[Verse 2: Hanz On]
Hookers in the kitchen, chemistry is the best recipe
Especially this shit, I'm takin' on bets
Pressure cookers, percolate 'em like chefs
Meth labs here to the West, wools on them gear trims grassed
Mr. Barker, General, front and center (What up?)
Got them burners wit' them bodies on them, have me in cuffs
Killer's focused, slam it up in them trucks
Eyes low, grippin' the toast, trigger finger, playin' it close
You think it's a game? It's imperative, we show 'em we live
These niggas playin' wit' this money, funny how niggas die
They say it's over when the fat kid cry, ratchets fly here to the Chi'

[Bridge 2]
You think you can stop me from cookin'?
You cook whatever you like, as long it's that B work
These niggas be runnin' around in the street wit' everyday
Don't even think about usin' my grade A
You should try and stop me, bitch
You might also like[Verse 3: Streetlife]
I'm in the meth lab concoctin' another concoction
Decisions, decisions, just weighin' my options
The formula highly addictive, it's habit forming
Side effects life-threatenin', the surgeon's warnin'
I write a prescription just for meth abusers
Regulate your dose intake for heavy users
For generations, I been servin' these rap fiends
Babies born addicted to the metric, know what I mean?
You're recoverin', but you still use frequently
So wet your court hearin', judge show some leniency
Can't escape old habits, so you copy the new shit
Wit' your kids in your cars, see, pumpin' that Wu shit
We worldwide, supply and demand, I got the upper-hand
Check my passport, global support
Informant lands non-commercial goods, that raw and uncut
That got them breakin' bad at the gate for the re-up

[Outro: Method Man and Streetlife]
What up, Street?
Yo, what up, man?
We gon' put some "Welcome to the meth lab" on there
Man, you know, it's straight gutter shit, nigga
Yeah, you ready to get 'em this time?
Yeah, always, man
Alright, so I'm a leave it up to you
Go 'head, show 'em what you got7Embed

songs.full_title: The Riddler by Method Man
songs.title: The Riddler

description.plain: “The Riddler” was Method Man’s contribution to the Batman Forever soundtrack. RZA provided a eerie-but-accessible beat that sampled the 1960’s Batman TV show theme song, and it reached 56 on the Billboard Hot 100 (his fourth-highest single). In the video, Method Man raps with clips of Jim Carrey’s Riddler and a storyline where he, “Don Provolone,” eliminates a rival crime boss with a classic time bomb.

songs.full_title: Yonkers by Method Man
songs.title: Yonkers

description.plain:
Meth performed this freestyle while appearing on Tim Westwood’s radio show in 2011 along with U-God and Masta Killa.

He performed an earlier freestyle but upon hearing the Yonkers instrumental, a cue that the freestyle was over, he was so engrossed in the beat that he had to start spitting.

songs.full_title: Torture by Method Man
songs.title: Torture

description.plain:
This song is from Method Man second album Tical 2000: Judgment Day.



It debuted at number two on Billboard 200 chart, and number one on Top R&B/Hip Hop Albums chart, while selling 411,000 copies in its first week. On December 16, 1998, Tical 2000: Judgement Day was certified platinum in sales by RIAA. Upon its release, the album received mostly favorable reviews from music critics, though several disapproved of its over-abundance of skits.

This song explains what tortures his mind and how he fights against demons.

body.plain: Method Man’s “Talk Dirty” was originally released on DJ Lethal’s Soundcloud﻿ account in 2013, but officially surfaced in August of 2017 in order to promote of the release of his album Meth Lab 2. A music video for the track came out in October 2018.

songs.title: Spazzola
songs.title_with_featured: Spazzola (Ft. Inspectah Deck, Killa Sin, Masta Killa, Raekwon & Streetlife)

description.plain:
If you don’t know what “Spazzola” means, it’s an italian word for “brush”.



So with backup from Wu-Tang Clan groupmates Masta Killa, Inspectah Deck (who also produces the track) and Raekwon, and affiliates Streetlife and Killarmy member Killa Sin, Mef is brushing off these phony emcees with this Wu posse cut on his sophomore album, Tical 2000: Judgement Day.

The song samples “Call Me” by Aretha Franklin.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-GQSLe4OmIY

Rest In Peace, Aretha!

songs.full_title: Even If by Method Man
songs.title: Even If

description.plain: Produced by Erick Sermon and P. King, “Even if” was the 5th song on the “Nutty Professor II: The Klumps” soundtrack. It features a heavy, funky, uptempo bass line and has a bit of the grimy feel of earlier Wu sounds. If you like the uptempo beats, as well as the flow and nature of the lyrics on this song, then you will probably also like Method Man’s “Judgement Day”

description.plain:
Following Method Man and Redman’s “Hood Go Bang” collaboration on Wu-Tang Clan’s 2017 album, The Saga Continues, the duo reunites on “Wild Cats,” the second single from Meth Lab Season 2.

Johnny Blaze and his fellow emcees go to work solidifying their presence as hip-hop purists over a melodic backdrop of percussive and string instrumentals with a distinctive 1990’s feel to the beat.

songs.full_title: Play IV Keeps by Method Man (Ft. Inspectah Deck, Mobb Deep & Streetlife)
songs.title: Play IV Keeps
songs.title_with_featured: Play IV Keeps (Ft. Inspectah Deck, Mobb Deep & Streetlife)

description.plain:
With backup from Wu-Tang Clan affiliate Streetlife and groupmate Inspectah Deck, Mef teams up with the infamous Mobb Deep (Wu-Tang’s Loud Records labelmates at the time) for the second time on this posse cut from his sophomore album, Tical 2000: Judgement Day. The first being Extortion, which was released on Mobb Deep’s third studio album, Hell on Earth in 1996.

Rest In Peace, Prodigy.

I am the sword in the darkness

Whats the matter?

[Hook]

songs.full_title: World Gone Sour by Method Man
songs.title: World Gone Sour

description.plain:
Method man joins Biggie in the club of Dope Ass Commercial Raps. (Sorry Drake)

“World Gone Sour” was written to promote Sour Patch Kids candy as an advertising campaign created by the Mother New York ad agency. The song details the trouble that Sour Patch Kids candies create until you eat them. A video game was also created that took the player on “a journey from the perspective of a lost piece of candy finding its way to its ultimate destination – the human stomach”.

songs.full_title: Retro Godfather by Method Man
songs.title: Retro Godfather

description.plain: In the late ‘90s, it was the “Jiggy Era”. That’s when mainstream commercial cats such as Puff Daddy, Mase, Will Smith and others were “trying to take hip-hop and make that sh!t R&B” by sampling music from the '70s and '80s. So Meth here is makin’ fun of these wack a$$ rappers in the industry that be fakin' it.

[Verse 6: Redman]
Allow me to reintroduce -- nah, I don't need it
If you ain't got it since '92, nigga, beat it
Hop in the 4 of ya 7, black two-seater
Pull out a hammer, big as a vacuum cleaner
Nigga, I roll heavy, bitch, I roll steady

You better ask who the best rapper in ya hood

songs.full_title: Ice Cream Man by Method Man
songs.title: Ice Cream Man

description.plain:
This is a rare, unreleased freestyle by none other then the Panty Raider!

Notable future Wu-Tang productions sample this song, such as the hook for Raekwon’s “Ice Cream”, and a part beat in the Wu-Tang track,  “Severe Punishment”

songs.full_title: Ridin' for Outro by Method Man (Ft. Black Ice)
songs.title: Ridin’ for Outro

description.plain:
“Ridin' For Outro” is the closing track to Method Man’s third studio album, Tical 0: The Prequel. It was produced by Yogi and co-produced by Rich Mae.

The song is unique because it doesn’t feature any Meth vocals at all, and is solely performed by the dope Def Poet Black Ice. He tells the story of three ghetto teens who go out on a drive by. The song is a commentary about black-on-black violence and focuses on the ideology of these kids, who go out on a drive and will “kill and main another cat like there’s no shame in that.” They do it for the purpose of gaining street cred and defending their gang territory. He finishes the track by asking these “thieves of life” why are they hiding if there’s honor or street cred in what they do. The closing line sums it up nicely: “Recognize your deed to trife and decide what the fuck you ridin for.”

songs.full_title: Meth V.S. Chef Part II by Method Man
songs.title: Meth V.S. Chef Part II

description.plain:
About “Mef Vs Chef 2”

“Mef Vs Chef 2” is the sequel to the 1994 hit “Meth Vs. Chef” off of Method Man’s first solo album “Tical”.

 “Mef Vs Chef 2” released in 2010 with “Wu Massacre”, an album featuring only a portion of the group, Raekwon, Method Man, and Ghostface Killah.

songs.full_title: The Setup (2004 Tim Westwood Freestyle) by Method Man (Ft. Tim Westwood)
songs.title: The Setup (2004 Tim Westwood Freestyle)
songs.title_with_featured: The Setup (2004 Tim Westwood Freestyle) (Ft. Tim Westwood)

description.plain:
In 2004, Method Man appeared on Tim Westwood’s radio show and freestyled over the beat of Obie Trice’s “The Setup”

This freestyle wasn’t released until Tim Westwood posted it on his YouTube channel on May 12, 2016, about twelve years after it was first recorded.
